html:
Etymology 1[edit]

From ad- +‎ levō (“lift up, raise”), from levis (“light”).

Alternative forms[edit]

  • adlevō

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈal.le.woː/, [ˈal̠.l̠ɛ.woː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈal.le.vo/, [ˈal.lɛ.vɔ]

Verb[edit]

allevō (present infinitive allevāre, perfect active allevāvī, supine allevātum); first conjugation

  1. I lift or set up, raise
  2. (figurative) I lighten, lessen, alleviate, mitigate, reduce
  3. (figurative) I sustain, comfort, console
  4. (figurative) I raise up, make distinguished; enhance
Conjugation[edit]

Synonyms[edit]
  • (alleviate): alleviō, levō
Derived terms[edit]
  • allevāmentum
  • allevātiō
  • allevātor
Descendants[edit]
  • Corsican: addivà
  • Italian: allevare
  • Sicilian: aḍḍivari

Etymology 2[edit]

From ad- +‎ lēvō (“make smooth”), from lēvis (“smooth”).

Alternative forms[edit]

  • adlēvō

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /alˈleː.woː/, [al̠ˈl̠eː.woː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /alˈle.vo/, [alˈlɛː.vɔ]

Verb[edit]

allēvō (present infinitive allēvāre, perfect active allēvāvī, supine allēvātum); first conjugation

  1. I make smooth, smooth off or over
